results.title: Goldilocks and the three bears. The Little mermaid
results.creator_credit: Edward Bell, Libby Simon and Home Box Office
results.brief_description: Two animated and humorous adaptations of fairy tales for children. “Goldilocks and the three bears”: Goldilocks is a girl from a tropical village, an impish scallywag with an uncompromising attitude, unfazed even when getting others into strife. But when she wanders into a forest she meets a spider, snake and bat, who try to warn her off the three bears that could land her in serious trouble. This amusing and funky short underpins the values of friendship and selflessness. “The Little mermaid”: Beneath the hustle and bustle of Taipei international trading port, a secret underwater kingdom exists where a mermaid, Princess Mija and her best friend, a starfish named Nuri, live happily under the watchful eye of Queen Hul-muh-ni. At fifteen years of age, Mija’s life changes forever when she falls for a human prince and has to choose between love and life in the ocean with her family. Features the voices of Tia Carrere, Margaret Cho, Raven Symone, Alfre Woodard, Jennifer Lewis and Lou Rawls.

results.title: GoldenEye 007
results.brief_description: GoldenEye 007 inspired endless fun when it was released on the Nintendo 64 – just as long as you didn’t look at anyone’s screen or play as Odd Job. One of the first multi-player first-person-shooters for console, GoldenEye made everyone 007.

constellations_other.name: Gunslingers, good fellas and flea bags
constellations_other.description: Explore how a 1903 western changed the course of filmmaking and videogames by breaking the fourth wall.

constellations_other.name: Capturing first-person POV
constellations_other.description: A comparison of how videogames and feature films have used first person POV shots and sequences and how (for the latter) camera technology has impacted on this.

recommendations.quote: There's never been a better adaptation of film into a videogame than Golden Eye. For the first time, up to four players could shoot it out on one TV screen and take control of one of some of cinema's best heroes and villains. And yes, Odd Job is cheating.

results.title: Golden braid
results.creator_credit: Paul Cox, Paul Ammitzboll, Santhana Naidu, Film Victoria and Illumination Films (AU)
results.brief_description: Bernard is an eccentric clockmaker; Terese is the sultry young Salvation Army worker with whom he is having an affair. Obsessed by the past, he finds a golden braid in an 18th century cabinet and immerses himself in the pursuit of a fantasy. It is up to Terese to lure him away from the ghost of the past, reignite their passion and seduce him back to reality.

results.title: Gold diggers' ballad: the watercolours of S.T.Gill (1818-80)
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: The famous watercolours by S. T. Gill reflect the optimism and feeling or spirit of the goldrushes. The gold diggers’ expressive faces and activities show the tremendous fever and hunger after gold in the 1850’s in Victoria. The paintings are presented with a background of Australian ballads with guitar accompaniment.

results.title: Going to blazes
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Look at Life”.
A survey of fire-fighting services in Britain. Over 35,000 fire-fighters, some full-time, some part-time keep constant watch for outbreaks of fire in town or country. Shows something of life on and off duty with units of the Glasgow and London fire services; visits a Fire Research Station where experts study the cause and effect of fire. Narrated by Tim Turner.
